DOC.HEAD: Other Nations Denounce Romanian Repression
Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 16th `In Prague' with opposition reaction; picks up 17th pvs `Poland's parliament'
With AM-Romania Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Leaders of East and West were united Tuesday in denouncing Romania's Stalinist regime for the bloody repression of protesters. Some reports said hundreds of people were killed when Romanian security forces opened fire over the weekend on demonstrators protesting the harsh rule of President Nicolae Ceausescu, the last autocrat in the Soviet bloc. Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze of the Soviet Union said that, if the reports of bloodshed were true, ``I can only express my very profound regret. We are categorically opposed to the use of force.'' Shevardnadze was at a meeting of about 200 members of the European Parliament in Brussels. There was no comment in Beijing, where the Chinese government crushed a peaceful pro-democracy movement with tanks on June 4-5. In Washington, White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said: ``The repressive measures undertaken by the Romanian government are totally unjustified and stand in stark contrast to the positive changes taking place elsewhere in Eastern Europe.'' A minister in the British Foreign Office, William Waldegrave, warned Romanian officials of what may lie ahead. ``Those in the security services, those working for the state, should recognize that a day of reckoning will come for them as it has come for the East Germans and others,'' he said. ``The right thing for them to do ... is to represent the true will of the Romanian people and put an end to this regime.'' Stan Soare, the Romanian ambassador, was summoned to receive a protest expressed in ``the strongest possible terms'' a British government spokesman said, and responded by ``resorting to the tired old formula of alleging interference in Romania's internal affairs.'' In its first protest to another member of the Soviet bloc, Bulgaria expressed ``serious concern'' to the Romanian Embassy in Sofia over the closing of the frontier. Romania closed its borders Monday allowing passage only to diplomats and other officials. Foreign ministers of the 12 European Community nations denounced the violence and several governments lodged official protests with Romanian diplomats. A statement by the 12 foreign ministers issued in Brussels said Ceausescu's regime was ``turning its back on all the commitments concerning human rights to which it has subscribed'' in the 1975 Helsinki agreements on human rights. Ceausescu ``is capable only of repressing by force the legitimate aspirations of the Romanian people to freedom,'' they said. Thousands of exiled Romanians were said to be planning a rally Thursday in London. In Prague, the Czechoslovak Foreign Ministry said: ``We resolutely protest the use of army and police against demonstrators.'' Vaclav Havel, the opposition leader and presidential candidate, said to reporters: ``When and if we have greater influence on Czechoslovakia's foreign policy ... we'll be able to do more for Romanians and Hungarians in Romania who are being killed by this terrible, Dracula-like person.'' A statement from Civic Forum, Havel's opposition group, said Czechoslovkia was ``learning with horror of the brutal intervention'' and was ``deeply shaken.'' Poland's parliament passed a resolution saying Romanian ``authorities used force with exceptional brutality. Even children were the targets of shooting.'' Austria's Foreign Ministry said its protest of ``catastrophic human rights practice in Romania'' was rejected by the Romanian charge d'affaires, Marian Radu, who also was unwilling ``to give expedient information verbally on the situation in Romania.'' In neighboring Hungary, feelings ran high because up to 1.7 million ethnic Hungarians live in Transylvania, the area of western Romania where the violence occurred. Premier Miklos Nemeth said ``anachronistic regimes opposed to progress cannot remain in place'' if Europe is to be united. Nepszabadsag, the official party of the Socialist _ formerly Communist _ Party, said: ``History has already witnessed the reign of regimes, not so long ago, that showed off their strength with tanks before being overthrown by the rage of the people.''
